;

;After briefly entering the live broadcast room, a domestic beauty brand established for more than two years decided not to enter the show again.

;

;This is both a fame and fortune fair and a place at the forefront of the limelight. The most recent farce was on September 10, 2023, when super anchor Li Jiaqi criticized netizens while selling Huaxizi eyebrow pencil. The turmoil has been postponed to this day, and the Huaxizi brand has become the target of public criticism.

;

;Many people in the industry are re-examining the sales ecology of anchors bringing goods. A brand manager Chu Shi (pseudonym) is also a melon-eater. For her, the high commissions and pit fees required by big anchors are difficult for small brands to resist.

;

;The "last straw" that caused Chu Shi to give up the live broadcast was exactly a live broadcast. The brand invited a top anchor with tens of millions of fans, and the position fee was about 70,000 yuan, with an agreed sales guarantee of 210,000 yuan. They have high expectations and regard it as the "most important event" since its inception.

;

;But in the end, the leading anchor only sold a few thousand yuan, and did not refund the corresponding amount according to the contract. Chu Shi called this incident a "trigger". Although she felt that the business was unhealthy before, she was willing to abide by the rules of the industry. This time she was in the whirlpool and felt chilled: "Given such a high commission, there are still pitfalls. For a bit fee, a brand like ours cannot play like that."

;

;The brand went to the police station to report the crime, and then won the lawsuit through litigation. However, the refunded fees have not yet been received, and the anchor is still active in the live broadcast room.

;

;“So much profit goes to the host”

;

;For this new brand, the first “obstacle” to live broadcast admission sounds humble: identifying the reasons for rejection.

;

;Chu Shi and the others contacted thousands of anchors and bloggers. Chu Shi recalled: “In the first year, we really hoped to increase the brand’s exposure through some experts. I put a lot of effort into promoting it and its popularity. But the result is really not very good.”

;

;Sending products to popular live broadcast rooms is the preferred way for small brands to gain popularity. Data from the live broadcast e-commerce industry blue book released by the China Institute of Metrology and other units show that in the first half of 2023, the sales of live broadcasts on key monitored e-commerce platforms reached 1.27 trillion yuan, with more than 110 million live broadcasts and more than 70 million live products. , the number of active anchors exceeds 2.7 million.

;

;Following the anchor's product selection process, they will communicate with the other party's business personnel and wait for feedback. If there is no feedback, it means it is inappropriate by default. It’s like rushing through the sand, “maybe less than 10% of anchors or business people will reply to us in this link.”    

;

;At first Chu Shi would feel confused, not knowing where he was stuck. Later, the picture gradually became clearer, "In fact, it is not the product at all, but the dissatisfaction with the price or commission."

;

;She found that anchors would focus on promoting the same product in various categories, making it particularly difficult for new products to emerge. The products that were strongly promoted by the anchors were actually the ones for which the brand offered high commissions. “For example, there are several products we know that offer commissions of 60 to 70 points, and they have already sold to the top in that category. ".

;

;70% commission means that if a product sells for 100 yuan, 70 yuan will be given to the anchor. The remaining costs should cover product development, raw materials, packaging materials and other costs, as well as warehousing logistics, site and labor costs.

;

;“We think this business is very unhealthy.” Chu Shi believes that high commissions force costs to be reduced. “So much profit is given to the anchors. They charge such high commissions, but they do not Without creating corresponding social value and providing more jobs, the profits of upstream brands and the supply chain have been reduced. Brands can only continue to reduce costs, and their products will become worse and worse, and the treatment of employees will also be worse. It’s getting worse.”

;

;Four or five years ago, she worked with anchors for beauty brands at the time, with commissions ranging from 20% to 30%. However, the live broadcast ecosystem gradually evolved. “From the year before last to last year, the commissions continued to increase. It’s rising. I don’t think it’s because the anchors are raising the price, it’s because the industry is too complicated, whether it’s beauty or live streaming, it’s all too complicated.”

;

;Beauty is recognized as one of the most popular fields. Nanshan, co-founder of the beauty MCN organization May Beauty, also feels the same way. Although there is a lot of beauty traffic on the platform, there are also a lot of people entering the platform. "I think it started to roll out in 2019 and 2020, and every year it is better than before. He kept curling more and more without stopping."

;

;The price of the volume, the mechanism of the volume, the content of the volume, the capital of the volume... the prices of things of the same quality are constantly falling in the competition, but the commissions for the anchors are gradually increasing. "I think this volume is good in all aspects." , product homogeneity is also very serious, and every price range is full of competitors."

;

;You Wuyang, director of Hangzhou Xijiang New Retail Research Institute and former deputy director of Alibaba Research Institute, told Southern Weekend reporters that taking eyebrow pencils as an example, from the perspective of raw material processing fees, including factory delivery The cost plus tax may be less than 10 yuan. The biggest cost of cosmetics is sales expenses. Previously, this part included marketing and channel expenses, that is, advertising, celebrity endorsements, channel deduction fees, and profits from offline wholesalers and agents. Now, if you sell through live e-commerce, it is a direct retail. The most important ones are traffic fees, advertising fees, anchor commissions for bringing goods, and pit fees. "These fees account for a very high proportion."

;

;You Wuyang pointed out that the biggest problem with the current live broadcast sales system is the trend of low prices. “After the emergence of live broadcast e-commerce, China’s retail market has been turned upside down. Everyone is fighting for low prices. "If a company has no profits, it will have no money to do product research and development and innovation, and bad money may drive out good money."

;

;Only care about three points: price, commission, and pit fee

;

;Price and gifts are the key points when attracting consumers to place orders in the live broadcast room. At this point, super The head anchor does have a higher say.

;

;Qiao Lei (pseudonym), the person in charge of a domestic brand who once sent products to Li Jiaqi’s live broadcast room, told Southern Weekend reporters that Li Jiaqi’s pit fee one or two years ago was “not expensive,” “about 8. "More than 10,000 yuan", the commission is 30 to 40%, which is almost the same as other anchors. But Li Jiaqi's prices are very low, even at prices the merchant himself has "never sold before." "He doesn't care how much you originally sold them for, he will only tell you 'how much I want to sell them for.'"

;

; "He will demand 'I am the lowest', but he will not tell you openly. He will only tell you a price to see if you can give it." Qiao Lei said that both parties It is also necessary to sign a price guarantee agreement to ensure that there will be no lower prices, including the brand's own live broadcast room.

;

;This condition is almost harsh, but a large number of businesses are still willing to accept it. Even now, there are still small brands that are eager to get into the super live broadcast room and are waiting hard. Lillian (pseudonym) is the person in charge of branding and e-commerce at a start-up company that makes functional skin care products. For her, the road to Li Jiaqi’s live broadcast room has not yet been opened. “I have been following them for half a year, and I still have During the data review stage.”

;

;;

;

;Like Li Jiaqi (first from left) Super anchors will undoubtedly play a key role in the sales of small brands. Visual China Pictures

;

;In comparison, Chu Shi has come into contact with "very few anchors who are truly professional." Brands provide product selling points, and anchors follow the script. "They rarely ask us professional questions about products." , because today’s anchors have too many choices, and merchants of all sizes are waiting for them to deliver products. They don’t know the raw materials, ingredients and functions of the products. What they care about most are three points: How much is the price, how much is the commission, and is there any pit fee?"

;

;Lin Mo (pseudonym), an anchor who has been doing live broadcasts for five years, told Southern Weekend reporters that she would learn about the product information before the live broadcast. Go to the live broadcast room every hour and communicate with the operation about the overall situation. During the live broadcast, consumers are mainly told three pieces of information: how favorable the price of this product is, how easy it is to use, and when and in what scenario it will be needed. If consumers are tempted but are still hesitant, they will emphasize the accompanying gifts and the decreasing inventory, "to force another order."

;

;According to Chu Shi’s observation, this is because the time to explain each product in the live broadcast room is very limited. Within a few minutes, the strength of the discount is reflected in order to impress users and make them purchase. "Use 'Quantity' is the fastest way for them to reflect the value of the product."

;

;Lin Mo has been a brand external anchor for a long time, and has worked with 30 or 40 brands. She is charged by the hour. "Selling more or less all depends on my own professional ethics and KPIs." There is not a lot of pressure on sales.” Recently, she decided to go it alone and collect commissions for selling goods. The more she sold, the more she earned, which gave her a greater sense of urgency.

;

;In addition, the platform will analyze the live broadcast data in real time, display the product placement expenses, sales volume and total sales of the day, and also conduct vertical comparisons. Increasingly intuitive data also tests the ability of anchors.

;

;The game mechanism between brands and anchors

;

;It is not easy to create a super anchor. May Beauty, where Nanshan is located, once failed to become a super anchor.

;

;This MCN organization has incubated more than 60 beauty experts. Nanshan recalled that the company originally “wanted to go towards the top.” At the end of 2021, they tried to support a beauty blogger with more than 10 million fans. At his peak, the blogger could bring in 5 to 6 million yuan in goods per sale. But they soon discovered that the top anchors were "not that easy to do" and it was difficult to obtain "a particularly good mechanism". The frequency of live broadcasts could not be increased, and the commission rate was relatively low. It was very likely that "the work was in vain and no money was made."

;

;One of the keys to being stuck in the top spot is the mechanism, that is, the brand merchants give the anchors product prices, gift configurations, commission sharing or other incentive resources. The differences in the mechanisms obtained by different anchors are obvious. Nanshan compared its own anchors with the leading anchors in the industry. The same shampoo was sold in both live broadcast rooms for 119 yuan for two bottles of 1,000 ml. At the head anchor, those who place orders can get an extra 400 to 500 ml of shampoo, but they may only get 100 to 200 ml.

;

;Sales that exceed brand expectations, make products a hit, have good daily video and live broadcast data, and excellent business negotiation skills can all help anchors get better mechanisms, "If Without a good mechanism, it will be difficult for users to continue paying for it."

;

;But Nanshan also observed that compared with the previous two years, brands have made less and less "sacrifice" in terms of mechanism. "In 2021, brands are more willing to sacrifice some mechanisms for anchors. For example, if he sells it for 119 yuan in his flagship store, he may give 99 yuan to our live broadcast room."

;

;You Wuyang pointed out, The relationship between the brand and the anchor is essentially a game. The brand previously offered low prices in the hope of attracting fans to its official website account and paying direct attention to the brand itself through the use of anchors to promote products. Anchors need to keep the products in the live broadcast room low-priced, maintain their original fans, and increase their value.

;

;The price of the product in the live broadcast room, the commission ratio that the anchor can get, and the gifts for consumers are all the focus of the game. In August 2023, Nanshan negotiated a cooperation with an anchor with one million fans at a price of 180,000 yuan, including two or three short videos, two live broadcast warm-ups and one special live broadcast, and brought five products. The main demands of brands are to reduce commissions and reduce gifts.

;

;Both parties held the mechanism table in their hands, went through two or three rounds of meetings and discussions, and finally chose to take a step back. The average commission has dropped from about 31% to 28%, and the product has gone from 119 yuan for two 600ml bottles and a 150ml gift to 128 yuan for two bottles and a 300ml gift, which is equivalent to "getting three bottles at once for 128 yuan." Both parties are satisfied with the results. After two or three live broadcasts, the brand's initial investment "will come back."

;

;Nanshan mentioned that some brands have also formed new cooperative relationships with anchors. That is, before the product is launched, the brand will let the anchor participate in product development, and the brand will communicate with the anchor: "I "How much do you think is appropriate for the product?" "I want to change the parts that are not suitable yet." The two parties will lengthen the line of cooperation.

;

;“Because anchors have a characteristic, they understand consumers better, which will make the entire industry chain closer to consumers.” Li Yongjian, director of the Research Office of the Institute of Financial Strategy of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, pointed out that the relationship between brands and anchors In-depth cooperation between enterprises is relatively beneficial, can improve the efficiency of the supply chain, and is conducive to the rapid formation of domestic brands. However, we need to be wary that some anchors may take advantage of consumers' trust to further squeeze consumers. "(Remember) you represent the interests of consumers and help them find high-quality and low-priced products."

;

;Live streaming is still the direction of this MCN organization’s efforts in 2023. Nanshan’s basis is that consumers’ minds have been formed and they have the habit of buying things in live broadcast rooms on a daily basis. At the same time, live broadcast consumption behavior has become more rational. In addition to price, the suitability of the product will also be considered. “At this time, we use live broadcasts to In this way, we can 'grow' users and let them place orders."

;

;;

;

;In May 2023, a beauty e-commerce company in Hangzhou conducted a live broadcast . Pictures and texts are irrelevant. Visual China Map

;

;Where is the “ceiling” of live streaming e-commerce?

;

;Different brands enter the live broadcast room for different purposes. Qiao Lei said that for some big brands, live broadcast is just a channel, and they value the "grass planting" effect more than the amount of goods brought by the anchor. New brands and small brands are different. They need to "plant grass" and "mow grass". They hope to have enough sales volume, return the cooperation costs, and increase the turnover rate of goods. As for himself, the more important purpose is promotion.

;

;The effect is obvious. Li Jiaqi’s live broadcast brought hundreds of thousands of visitors to their store. “The original daily sales were 50,000 to 60,000 yuan. Maybe after he helped us bring goods through the live broadcast, , the daily sales reached 80,000 to 90,000, and the influence is expanding.”

;

;However, Li Yongjian pointed out that "reliance on chefs" is the biggest shortcoming of the live broadcast e-commerce ecosystem. For a new brand, telling a good brand story, making good products, and forming brand power are the most basic. It is very difficult to rely on top anchors to build a brand. "There are individual (successful) cases, but whether this case can be sustained, if If there is no brand power and product power, I think it is questionable."

;

;In his view, the "ceiling" of live broadcast e-commerce has appeared. He said that the basic logic of e-commerce is to stretch the supply chain and shorten the marketing chain. "Now suddenly there is an additional anchor, and 25% and 30% will be cut off. This business logic itself has problems." An imperfect profit distribution mechanism, a chaotic price system, and uneven development among anchors are all chaos in the live broadcast ecosystem, which has led to new problems, such as data traffic fraud and false orders.

;

;For Qiao Lei, the development of the live broadcast field has become mature. Regardless of whether the number of fans is large or small, the age of the audience is old or young, and whether the field is hot or cold, there are corresponding competitors. "In fact, there are people occupying every card slot, and any vertical track It’s basically all covered.”

;

;Qiao Lei found that in the past, each platform and each anchor had its own audience and had little influence on each other. However, during major promotion periods such as "618" and "Double Eleven", several The overlapping rate of consumers on the platform will be significantly higher, and all anchors carrying goods will be drawn into the same arena, making the strength of their competitiveness particularly obvious. "When it comes to large-scale promotions, the living space of tail anchors is actually very small, and head anchors are still the main ones."

;

;Similarly, small brands that are not very competitive will also choose to participate in major promotions. "Lie down" to protect yourself and withdraw from the fierce battlefield. Lillian said that traffic costs will increase during major promotions. She does not have the ability to seize traffic and divide the market, and will actively avoid the war. "Normally (big promotion festivals) we are not anxious, we just put it away."

;

;Zhao Haoxing, a professor at the School of Economics at Zhejiang Gongshang University and a member of the Zhejiang Provincial Consumption Promotion Expert Committee, told Southern Weekend reporters that the current ecology of the live broadcast field is not sound. On the other hand, they have raised the sales price and made huge profits. All the dividends have been concentrated on the Internet celebrities. The profit distribution in the ecosystem is seriously unreasonable. This phenomenon must be broken in the future." He suggested that the market regulatory authorities strengthen supervision and hoped that the supply chain would become more mature and complete, with reasonable distribution of upstream and downstream profits.

;

;He said that the live broadcast industry has now reached a period of transformation. Various types of vertical industry chain live broadcasts, factory live broadcasts, and expert live broadcasts are all playing a greater role, and "small but beautiful, small and specialized" have emerged. Features, this is also the development direction of "future version 2.0 live broadcast".

;

;On October 29, 2021, Xu Anhua attended the screening of "The First Incense" in Shanghai Post-communication activities. ;(Photo courtesy of interviewee);

;

;On the Beginning of Winter in 2021, Xu Anhua was in a good mood. She flew from Beijing to Xiamen , planning to make this the last stop of her trip to the mainland. On May 22, 2019, the new film "The First Incense" directed by Xu Anhua started filming in Gulangyu Island, Xiamen. Two and a half years later, she returned here with the film. At the screening event, some audience members whispered to each other: "I heard that this movie was not shot well?"

;

;"It is a good thing to have discussions." Talking about the reputation controversy of "The First Incense" , Xu Anhua's attitude is very calm. Although her career has encountered many failures and doubts, the rating of "The First Incense" on Douban is only 5.6, becoming Xu Anhua's lowest score in 43 years of acting.

;

;Producer Liu Ren told Southern Weekend reporters: "Due to various reasons, "The First Incense" did not have a premiere. The director came to Xiamen this time to thank those who helped us during the previous filming. It is completely We paid for it at our own expense. The reason for the word-of-mouth controversy of "The First Incense" is very complicated, which has nothing to do with the current publicity and distribution rules of the film industry. Ann (Ann Hui's English name) is not indifferent to this, but she often I cheered her up and said it didn't matter. Although she was angry, she would not be sad. She would fight back, learn from experience and continue filming - you see she is a confrontational person with a revolutionary heart."

;

;" The filming of "The First Incense" will most likely fail"

;

;"I have been working on this project for seven years, and it is really a long story." Liu Ren, the producer of "The First Incense" said, " "The First Incense" is the first project I produced. The company "Blue Bird" was handed over to me by my teacher Xia Meng (note: Hong Kong movie star, well-known patriot) before her death. She told me to make good movies. , so I asked director Xu Anhua to shoot "The First Incense"."

;

;The film adaptation of Zhang Ailing's "The First Incense" has been going on for decades. During her lifetime, Zhang Ailing had liked the movie star Lin Dai to play the heroine Ge Weilong. Later, Lin Dai committed suicide and the matter was ignored. In the 1980s, Jade Bird Film Company, founded by Xia Meng, started a trend of co-productions between Hong Kong and the Mainland, investing in three films: "The Wrath of the Sea", "Heroes from Ancient Times" and "Back to Time". Xia Meng also considered purchasing the copyright of "The First Incense", but due to some changes in the production environment of Hong Kong films, Xia Meng left the film industry, and the matter was delayed again. In the 1990s, Xu Feng, the producer of "Farewell My Concubine" purchased the copyright of the novel and contacted Yang Dechang, but due to various reasons, he did not make the film. It wasn't until 2014 that Liu Ren, who was working in the Shanghai publishing industry at the time, was chatting with friends and came up with the idea of ​​adapting Zhang Ailing's novel into a movie.

;

;Among Zhang Ailing's many novels, Liu Ren chose "The First Incense". After some twists and turns, in 2015, he bought the five-year adaptation rights of the novel from Song Yilang, the copyright holder of Zhang Ailing, and set out to find his favorite director. In 2016, he received Xu Anhua's approval to serve as the film's producer. "Ann told me at the time how difficult it would be to adapt this movie, and that adapting "The First Incense" would most likely fail. She suggested that I find a young director to make it. Because even if this movie doesn't work well and is controversial, young people People have a young person’s perspective, and it’s a good thing to have controversy.” Liu Ren told Southern Weekend reporters.

;

;From 2016 to 2019, Liu Ren has been doing various tasks for the filming of the movie, encountering various accidents and misfortunes. Seeing that the adaptation copyright is about to expire, the management proposed to ask Xu Anhua to be the director. . At that time, Ann Hui had just completed the movie "When Will There Be a Bright Moon". She compared several job offers at hand and finally decided to take on the directorship of this film. She hired someone who had collaborated with her in the stage play "The Story of the Golden Lock" Writer Wang Anyi served as the screenwriter, and the prototype of the movie "The First Incense" gradually took shape.

;

;Xu Anhua was born in 1947. When "The First Incense" is released in October 2021, she will be 74 years old. In 2020, when the COVID-19 epidemic broke out, Xu Anhua completed the post-production of the film and learned that the Venice Film Festival was going to award the Lifetime Achievement Award to him. She is the first female director in the world to receive this honor, which is seen as a victory for female filmmakers around the world. Xu Anhua delivered a speech in English when receiving the award, saying that he would go back to help more young people so that they would also have the opportunity to receive the Lifetime Achievement Award in the future.

;

;In October 2020, a documentary "Making Movies Well" chronicling Xu Anhua's 40 years in film premiered at the Hong Kong International Film Festival. The director of this work, Wen Nianzhong, has served as the director of several of Xu Anhua's films. The art director showed the audience some fragments of Xu Anhua's life in his later years from the perspective of friends and collaborators.

;

;Anhua Xu has never been married and has almost no emotional experience. She once said, "Movies are my husband or wife, and literature is my mistress." She only has eyes for movies. She often falls down when she is too involved in her work. The most anxious thing is that there are no movies to shoot.

;

;Liu Ren told the Southern Weekend reporter: "When we were filming in Gulangyu Island, Ann fell in the bathroom one day and landed on the back of her head, which was very scary. She sent me a message as soon as she regained consciousness and said , 'Xiao Liu, I fell, I dare not move, can you come and see me?' I rushed to take a look, and there were purple bruises from the back of her head to her neck, and I quickly took her for an MRI. Tell me, the first thing that comes to mind is that if something really happens, call A Kwan (director Kwan Jin Peng) to come (replace her). Ann is really a person who works hard for the movie, so many times I Forget that she is an old man in her seventies, we will continue to cooperate in the future, and I hope she can make two more movies before she is 80 years old."

;

;November 6, 2021, Despite negative reviews, the movie "First Incense" still grossed more than 60 million yuan at the box office, and is expected to become Xu Anhua's second-highest box office film in the mainland. The next morning, Southern Weekend reporters conducted an exclusive interview with Xu Anhua in Xiamen. At the end of the conversation, she suddenly said: "Let me ask you a question too. To be honest, what do you think of "The First Incense"?"

;

;;

;

;Xu Anhua based on Zhang Ailing's novel of the same name The film adaptation of "Half Life" (1997), starring Anita Mui (right) and Wang Zhiwen (left). ;(Information picture/picture);

;

;"Zhang Ailing has become an inviolable writer"

;

;; Southern Weekend:;;"The First Incense" has received so much criticism on the Internet this time. To be honest, I am a little surprised , judging from the ratings on Douban.com, this is the movie with the worst reputation in your career. I would like to know, what do you think of the word-of-mouth controversy of "The First Incense"? ;

;

;;Anna Hsu:;;I didn’t expect there to be such a loud voice, but I think if this drama doesn’t get good reviews, it’s good to be controversial. of. It’s great if everyone can openly talk about their ideas about the movie and discuss the show together. It would also be good to talk more about other social issues. Maybe because of the epidemic, everyone is a little confused, and we can take this opportunity to clarify some basic concepts. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;I have seen some interviews and you said you are filming After watching "Love in a Fallen City" and "Half a Lifetime", I no longer want to make another movie adapted from Zhang Ailing's work, but why did I continue to make "The First Incense"? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;It’s not that I don’t want to shoot Zhang Ailing. In fact, I really want to shoot it, but I really haven’t thought about how to shoot Zhang Ailing’s works so that the audience can accept them. In other words, how to shoot to make people feel that the artistic quality of the movie is even higher. After the filming experience accumulated in the first two films, I realized that adapting Zhang Ailing's works is very difficult to please. It is neither easy to please the Western (audience) nor the Chinese (audience). To be honest, "Half a Lifetime" was rejected by the Venice Film Festival. They originally enthusiastically asked me to bring the film to Venice, but after watching it, they felt that it was a very ordinary love movie. ;

;

;Later, "Half a Life" was screened in the United States, and a well-known film critic said that we could treat this movie as William Wyler (director of "Roman Holiday") This is a touching and decent romance film shot by a technically savvy director. They saw "Half a Lifetime" in this way, so I wasn't unaware of the consequences when I made "The First Incense."

;

;In fact, they couldn't tell the difference between the real scenes and the fake ones that we overcame huge difficulties to shoot. They also didn't understand the background of the characters and thought it was an ordinary "soap opera". Because they have never seen Zhang Ailing, we have made a difficult adaptation based on the original text, and we have done enough work. They don't think it is different from Hollywood movies in the 1940s.

;

;Both "The First Incense" and "Love in a Fallen City" have very long lines. These lines are particularly unpleasant in the movie, but if the sentences in the original work are not used, readers will not let them go. I. Zhang Ailing's readers will demand that your work be the same as or better than the original work, but I know that many of Zhang Ailing's stories are not creative, because her creativity lies in her writing method, not the story itself.

;

;I have never thought about how to make a good film. I can't make it into a niche art film because I won't get money. During this period, I heard various feedbacks and became more and more aware that the market had changed. What's more, over the years, Zhang Ailing has become an inviolable writer. There are many fanatical fans who are more familiar with Zhang Ailing than me. A slight mistake will be very troublesome. I am deeply aware of these problems, but I haven't figured out how to overcome them. .

;

;I made a story like this for the current "post-90s" and "post-00s" generations. They may not understand the relationship between the characters. They don't know who the uncle is, what the second wife is, and the life experience of the aunt. What's going on? It's not that they are ignorant, it's that they don't have these things in their experience. For example, if a girl loses her virginity in the countryside in the 1940s, she will be dipped in a pig cage. That's not the case now. It's understandable for girls to covet a comfortable life. That era was actually very hypocritical. No one talked about money, and a woman would not admit it even if she wanted money.

;

;Under such circumstances, I have to make the story understandable and reasonable for young audiences, while at the same time staying true to the original work. It is difficult to balance these. I'm not trying to defend myself because I can't take good pictures, I just want to share some of the problems I've experienced.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You seem to have said "The First Incense" and "The Fall of the City" Do you think it is better than the latter? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;Yes, definitely. It was completely wrong before, but now it may be a little deviated from the original work, but I did it on purpose. I shot "Love in a Fallen City" hoping to make it a very touching story, but in fact it should be the least touching story. It just has a seemingly good ending. This is Zhang Ailing's creativity. But because I grew up reading a lot of romantic novels, I wanted the hero and heroine to feel like they were "war-torn mandarin ducks." This was actually wrong and completely violated the spirit of the original work. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;"The First Incense" from preparation to filming What do you think is the most difficult part of the process? ;

;

;;Anna Hsu: ;;Just finding funds is already very difficult, but it wasn’t me who found it, it was the producer who looked for it for three years. . After I bought the copyright, people talked about how "The First Incense" was (good) and how Zhang Ailing was (good), but when it came time to actually pay for it, no one was there. I don't blame them, because it's easy to calculate the box office by just calculating it. This is a literary film, which may require huge funds. It may be difficult to recoup the scenery and costumes of that era. ;

;

;On the contrary, I think it is not a big problem to choose the actors and the filming team. Because of Zhang Ailing’s appeal, everyone is willing to give it a try. The second difficulty was choosing the location for filming, which was quite difficult. Later I chose Gulangyu Island. When it came time to actually shoot, because we already had such a mature team, there was no problem.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You mentioned that it is difficult to find money for this film, but it is relatively easy to find actors. Yes, but the most controversial aspect of this film is the selection of actors. Did you receive any interference from capital during the process of finding actors? For example, will they tell you who you should and should not choose from a box office perspective?;

;

;;Xu Anhua:;;There will be, but they are all normal discussions. , they didn’t give me much difficulty. ;

;

;;

;

;Anna Hui (left), costume director Emi Wada (middle), and producer Liu Ren (right) on the set of the movie "The First Incense". ;(Photo courtesy of interviewee);

;

;“I am no longer anxious about the box office”

;

;< strong>;Southern Weekend:;;In the documentary about you "Making Movies Well", you expressed directly that every time you shoot After finishing a movie, you will worry about the box office, which is a very anxious thing for you. Throughout your career, you have almost never stopped working, which is not easy in the Hong Kong film environment. Can you talk about your cooperation and competition with different film companies at different times? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;I don’t need to talk about the previous difficulties in detail, and starting from "The First Incense", what you just said The anxiety is gone because for me, the success of a movie is no longer entirely judged by the box office. In the 1970s and 1980s, Hong Kong (movies) could not do without selling money, so they would not be able to find the money for the next movie. I feel that as long as it can win an award, a small number of viewers will think it is particularly good, and if the director is well-known, he can still find investment. Of course, this does not mean that you will definitely be able to shoot the ideal thing, because investors still have to evaluate whether the film is profitable. But I realized that I don’t need to be anxious anymore. What I’m anxious about is that I won’t be able to film, not that others will scold me or that I won’t be successful, so this problem no longer exists. ;

;

;In retrospect, every drama has different difficulties. If I talk about it in detail, it seems to be a complaint, which is unnecessary. This is part of my job. If you don't accept it, don't do it. There is no benefit in complaining all the time.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Generally speaking of you, everyone will think of the artistic films you have made. , will say that you are very caring about society. In fact, you have also tried many types of movies, such as martial arts movies and horror movies. Are you influenced by the market when making these movies? ;

;

;;Anna Hsu: ;;In fact, "ghost movies" like "Ghost World" have never been popular, and few people have made them; martial arts movies are It was once popular, and I wanted to shoot it because I am a "martial arts fan." I only made a few movies that were purely for work, such as "Shanghai Vacation". It was because I was waiting for the next movie to start shooting. Someone told me that the director of "Shanghai Vacation" had quit and asked me if I wanted to film it. , I read the script and thought it was pretty good. I will only shoot a script if I agree with it, and I won’t shoot it if I don’t agree with it. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Everyone always has the feeling that Hong Kong movies as a whole are The environment is very commercial. Movies like "Into the Wrath" and "A Thousand Words" that you made are not mainstream enough and almost no one makes them. ;

;

;;Anna Hui: ;;That’s not true. There are actually many directors in Hong Kong who make these films, but the output is not large. I think there are at least a dozen or so. , such as Guan Jinpeng, Zhang Wanting, Luo Qirui, and Tan Jiaming, who was at the same time as us... Actually, there were many people making this kind of movies in the 1970s and 1980s, and I was not the only one. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Obviously there are some differences between you and them, such as 1982 You paid attention to the subject of Vietnamese refugees in 2008's "The Wrath of the Sea". At that time, few Hong Kong directors filmed people and events outside Hong Kong. Does this have anything to do with your personal experience? ;

;

;;Anna Hsu: ;;It has something to do with it. In 1978, I was working at TVB and wanted to make a realistic drama series "Under the Lion Rock". ;

;

;I chose to shoot this subject, so I did a lot of homework and even went to a refugee camp. I became interested in their previous lives in Vietnam and found that many of the refugees were actually Chinese. Their Chinatown was quite similar to the Macau where I lived when I was a child. I was particularly emotional about this kind of place and wanted to capture these scenes in the movie. .

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;So you have always paid special attention to social reality? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;I rarely put concepts first. I always see people and things first, think they are good, then think about them slowly, and finally Will work out a logic to answer various questions. For example, when telling the screenwriter why he chose such a story, many of them are considered after the fact. In the beginning, it is often based on impulse. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;I know the reason why you took over the filming of "First "Incense" actually has some connection with "Journey to the Angry Sea", because of the company Blue Bird. Why did Xia Meng invest in "Journey to the Angry Sea" given the general environment in Hong Kong at that time? ;

;

;;Anna Hsu: ;;It has always been difficult to find money for this kind of movies, but Xia Meng has her own ideals and her strong backing, they made this The film is not intended to make money at all, it is mainly to make a film with a sense of culture. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You won the award for your film debut "Crazy Heist" You were successful and won the Golden Horse Award; "Into the Furious Sea" won the Academy Award. You were less than 35 years old at the time, but in the following ten years, several of your films were not very satisfactory, until "Woman Forty" Your career has taken off, how did you survive this period? ;

;

;;Anna Hsu:;;I want to know why this is happening. Is there something wrong with the movie I made, or is there something wrong with me? I don’t understand society and Is there an audience? I was actually quite curious and wanted to know why some films were not good, so I continued to shoot whenever I could. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Looking back today, did you find this The reason? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;Yes, in fact, each film is different. Generally speaking, the period from 1985 to 1995 was the heyday of Hong Kong action movies. Workers in the entire industry are used to that way of working, and are completely uncooperative with our semi-industrial approach, which is similar to student homework. They all do several groups of things at the same time. ;

;

;I was not in a good mood at the time. I felt that I was out of tune with them and that I had not done a good job. Because the staff is very tired when shooting commercial films and doing several sets at the same time. I also feel that the entire environment does not support the kind of films I make. After 1994, this wave of climax ended, and Hong Kong's film industry began to slow down, and everyone almost returned to the state of one film at a time.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;During this process, have you not thought about the issue of transformation? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;I filmed "The Book of Swords and Enmities" in 1986, but it was unsuccessful. Around 1991, I filmed "Yakuza", a gangster film, but it was also unsuccessful. The main reason is that I really don’t like shooting action. I cooperate with the action director and leave it to him. When he comes to show me, I am not used to communicating repeatedly. In fact, the action director directs on the scene, and I should stay behind and constantly study with him how to shoot, but I don't like this form of cooperation very much. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;So after "Woman 40", you Only then do you find what kind of movie is more suitable for you - maybe a movie that doesn't have a particularly large investment but can maintain your own style? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;Yes, that’s true. ;

;

;;

;

;The film "Love in a Fallen City" (1984) adapted by Ann Hui based on Zhang Ailing's novel of the same name, with Chow Yun-fat (second from right) and Miao Qianren (first from right) playing the male and female protagonists. ;(Information picture/picture);

;

;"I am actually more like a mainland director"

;

;;Southern Weekend: ;;You are one of the first Hong Kong directors to come to the mainland to film. In 1985, when you were filming "Book, Sword and Enmity", you were in I have lived in the Mainland for a whole year. Later, your "Half Life" was regarded as a model of co-production films at that time. When it comes to movies such as "Jade Goddess of Mercy" and "The Golden Age", it can be said that mainland capital almost accounts for the main part. But you are not like directors such as Peter Chan who focus entirely on the mainland. Or like Tsui Hark, he can be regarded as a "Hong Kong New Wave" director like you, but he is also very comfortable shooting theme films like "Changjin Lake". ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;Yes. I think in the 1980s when I was filming "The Wrath of the Sea" and "The Book of Swordsman", the mainland's film industry was very backward. Now compared to Hong Kong, the mainland's film industry has become very developed. For example, if you walk into a late-stage company, everything has been arranged and it is very mature. ;

;

;Hong Kong commercial film directors have different ideas from mainland directors. They have their own creativity, but they focus entirely on the market and only pursue good-looking films. But in the Mainland, even directors of commercial films still have a set of ethics. If they want to express their stories, they must have a core theme before filming. I'm actually more like a mainland director, I need to have a theme running through the movie.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You majored in literature at the University of Hong Kong. I think you are You attach great importance to literature in movies, and you like to use some literary elements in movies, such as the poetry in "Man 40". I think these elements are the origins of the characters in your movies. Your movies are different from directors such as Wong Kar-Wai. The characters always have an origin. It may be a physical origin, or it may be a spiritual origin. This origin Often Mainland China. ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;Yes, these may be related to my experience, but they are not intentional. Sometimes they are not added by me, such as " The scenes of reciting ancient poems in "Man 40" were all original works by screenwriter An Xi. The things in "Autumn Regret on a Passenger's Journey" are real things. My grandfather taught me to recite poems, and I didn't add them deliberately. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You worked hard on the few movies you shot in the mainland With various explorations and attempts, "Aunt's Postmodern Life", "Jade Guanyin", "Golden Age", etc., almost every one of them is controversial. Especially the first two films, because they are modern dramas, people will think that you don’t understand life in the Mainland very well. ;

;

;;Anna Hsu: ;;Controversy is good, but there are indeed some gaps. For example, the audience sometimes doesn’t like the dubbing, and sometimes they don’t like the language. With accents, they are all different. They care a lot about whether the lines are spoken well, but we Cantonese don't really care about this. We just speak naturally and casually. There is no so-called training in the cadence of the lines. This is a big difference. I think that in the future I may still take photos of life in the Mainland, but it depends on the subject matter. Of course I can take photos if I can, but I’m afraid it will be more difficult because I don’t know a lot of the details of life. ;

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You have been here since "The Golden Age" Is it easier to circumvent these cultural barriers when filming period dramas? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;Yes, because sometimes I don’t understand the Internet. Especially in this Internet age, I don’t even know the basics of food, clothing, housing, and transportation. It’s completely different. For example, I don’t know how to interact with others or how to talk on the phone. ;

;

;"Directing is a profession for young people"

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;In 2020, you won the Lifetime Achievement Award at the Venice Film Festival. At that time, you said that you wanted to focus on cultivating the younger generation of filmmakers in the future. What kind of work might you do in this regard in the future? Your generation of directors is called the "Hong Kong New Wave." Do you think there will be a new wave of young directors from the Chinese-speaking region in the future? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;Just do it if you have the chance. I will not deliberately open a company. I am not good at doing these things. If there are any problems, it would be great if we all discuss them together, but it is not really a big deal. ;

;

;I talked about the "New Wave" so much that I couldn't stand it at first. In fact, at that time, some people who studied film from abroad returned to Hong Kong and started working in television stations. I happened to shoot a movie around the same time. At that time, the traditional film studio system was a little confused about where to go. A group of us made some realistic things for TV, and then we continued to film them. In fact, it was not the idea of ​​the French New Wave that revolutionized film history and language. It was quite prosperous at that time, and everyone had movies to shoot, and they were very happy.

;

;In fact, there have been good young people coming out in recent years, but they may not be called "new wave" because they are not so concentrated. Hong Kong is still very small. Looking at mainland directors from various film festivals, some young people make very good films. If they insist on making a few more films for a few years, they will become hardcore elements. This is the same as the "Hong Kong New Wave", except that It’s just named like this without much fanfare. In fact, your media can really give them more exposure.

;

;It is good to give young people opportunities, but there is no need to talk about helping young people and turn it into an unpreset slogan. I feel that what young people need is spiritual support, not running away. When you become a producer, if something goes wrong, do you replace the other person, or do you support him in doing something you don't agree with? I don't want to make this a full-time thing because I don't like managing people.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Can it be understood that you don’t want to care about others at work? , and don’t want to be controlled? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;No, making a movie is a highly collaborative job. How can you not cooperate with others? But I have some standards of my own. There are things that others can’t control, otherwise you’ll be wasting your money. There are some things that others can control, so you just need to know them. ;

;

;Of course, it also depends on the specific situation. For example, if you really want to make a certain movie, the bottom line may be lower, or the requirements may be higher. I maintain this flexibility. I can't tell myself how I will do it early on, because I might slap myself in the face later.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;You are 74 years old. I am really curious about how you are doing. Keep making movies. Many of your contemporaries and even some juniors have retired. ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;I have been asking this question myself. I never thought about overcoming any difficulties when I was working, because difficulties are certain, director This industry has something to do with your own inspiration and how much you want to take pictures. Some people feel that they want to make money or change careers when they are done shooting. I am afraid this is not because of any setbacks. It is actually difficult for a person to make movies all his life. Directing is a profession for young people. When you are over fifty, your physical strength cannot keep up, nor can you keep up with the times. ;

;

;Before filming "Women at Forty", when I was only in my forties, some friends told me to retire, but I just wasn't convinced and there was nothing I could do beyond making movies. of this matter. Of course, my example is just an isolated case, and it can be used as an encouragement to others, but it may not be of much use. You can’t make a fortune as a director, so you can keep filming as long as you like it.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;The mainland film market has been particularly prosperous in the past few years, and some people will have the idea to The illusion that you can gain some fame and fortune by becoming a director. ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;It doesn’t matter, as long as you figure out when to stop and why you are shooting. I think that when you do everything, you need to think clearly about why you do it, not just follow what others do. The best thing to do as a director is to constantly challenge yourself. If it was the same every time, the same thing coming and going, I probably wouldn't continue filming. In addition, in this rapidly changing world and society, the director's position is changing rapidly. ;

;

;I have been thinking about filming something that people will want to watch, and maybe filming a TV series. To be honest, the most important thing is to keep healthy. Without this, you can't do anything. As for what you want to shoot and whether you will achieve success, these are not guaranteed.

;

;;Southern Weekend:;;Speaking of age restrictions, even older people in Europe and the United States are still filming There are quite a few directors, such as Clint Eastwood, who is still making movies in his nineties, but there are almost no such directors in Asia. Do you think it has something to do with culture? ;

;

;;Xu Anhua: ;;Of course. Their team is more suitable for older directors, because the division of labor is relatively detailed and the shooting system is relatively complete. They may only shoot for 6 hours a day. They are all moderate and it is easier. They are not as hard-working as ours, but The phenomena you mentioned are actually very rare. ;

;
